subject: Re: How to test main() method ??
msgSnippet: Hi David Thank for the tip about testing the main method, that is pretty neat. But as a good practice, we should not put any business logic inside the main
messageBody:
Hi David

Thank for the tip about testing the main method, that is pretty neat.

But as a good practice, we should not put any business logic inside
the main mehtod, hence there should be no need to test the main method.


David J

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Jackman" <david.jackman@f...> wrote:
> It's the same as testing any other method. Set up the test, call the
> method, then verify the output.
>
> For example:
>
> public void testMain()
> {
> // Set up the input and output streams
> System.in = new ByteArrayInputStream("1\n".getBytes());
> ByteArrayOutputStream output = ByteArrayOutputStream();
> System.out = new PrintStream(output);
> // Call the main method
> MyClass.main(new String[] {});
> // Verify the output
> assertEquals("You typed a 1.", output.toString());
> }
>
>
> ________________________________
>

>
> Thanks David. How are the static methods tested? (its my first few
> days into JUnit and I am yet to write test for a static method). My
> main method asks the user to enter 0-4. As you might have guessed it
> by now, in the body it has a switch statement. The switch based on
> whether the input was 0-4, calls upon some method from a different
> class.
>
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Jackman" <david.jackman@f...>
> wrote:
> > If your main is simply instantiating an object and calling a method on
> > it, then it may not need to be tested. If it has any logic at all, it
> > should be tested. You can test this method just like testing any
> other
> > static method. If your main reads from stdin and writes to stdout
> then
> > you will want to override these streams in your tests so you can
> control
> > the input and verify the output.
> >
> > ..David..
